repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.unittitle: Mount Vernon Seminary and College Memorabilia collection
did.abstract: This collection contains memorabilia from the Mount Vernon Seminary and College campuses. The Mount Vernon Seminary began in 1875 as a private high school and junior college for women, founded by Elizabeth J. Somers. The George Washington University initially affiliated with Mount Vernon College, and ultimately acquired the college's property and legacy in 1999. Material in this collection dates between circa 1850 and 2000.
did.physloc: Materials may be stored off-site, and may require additional retrieval time. Please contact the Special Collections Research Center for more information.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into 5 series: Timothy Cole (1852-1941) Etchings, Suzanne J. Allan (nee Johnson) memorabilia, Textiles, Metals, and Chasseriau Etchings.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: The Mount Vernon Seminary began in 1875 as a private high school and junior college for women, founded by Elizabeth J. Somers. The George Washington University initially affiliated with Mount Vernon College, and ultimately acquired the college's property and legacy in 1999.
The first school of higher education available to women in Washington, D.C., Mount Vernon Seminary and College had five different locations throughout its history:
1875-1880: Elizabeth Somers began tutoring the young daughters of prominent Washington men in her home at 204 F Street, NW in Washington, DC.
1880-1917: The school moved to 1100 M Street, NW where it expanded rapidly to include three additional houses, a courtyard, tennis court, and basketball court.

1917-1942: Having outgrown its M Street location, the school moved to a 15-acre campus on Nebraska Avenue, NW. In 1942, the United States Navy took over the Nebraska Avenue campus to use its facilities for the war effort.
1943-1946: The school resumed courses in February 1943 at the top floor of a Garfinckel's department store building in the Spring Valley neighborhood of Washington, D.C.

1946-1999: Between 1944 and 1946, the school built a new 21-acre campus located on Foxhall Road in Washington, D.C. using money granted to the college by the United States Navy in compensation for the military takeover of its property.

The last Seminary class graduated in 1969, and the school was then officially renamed to Mount Vernon Junior College. In 1976, Mount Vernon College became an accredited four year college. In 1997, the Board of Trustees decided that the College would close as an independent institution. As of June 30, 1999, Mount Vernon became affiliated with The George Washington University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains memorabilia from the Mount Vernon Seminary and College campuses including textiles, metal objects, etchings, and personal memorabilia. The material listed in this guide is processed and available for use, but there is additional material in the collection that is minimally processed and may not be available for research. Please contact Special Collections for more information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Please cite unpublished materials in the following way:
Please provide the title and date of item, catalog number (if applicable it will be found written on the folder), name of the collection, name of the repository, and location of the repository.

Example: James Oglethorpe to the Trustees, 13 January 1876, RG0001 Series 1, Box 4, Folder 3. Records of the Board of Trustees, Special Collections Research Center, Gelman Library, The George Washington University, Washington, D.C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains twenty signed wood-engravings by American artist Timothy Cole. The etchings were at one time displayed on the Nebraska Avenue campus of Mount Vernon Seminary and College. They date between 1896 and 1912, with the bulk dating between 1896 and 1899.

c.bioghist:
Biographical / HistoricalTimothy Cole:(b London, 16 April 1852; d Poughkeepsie, NY, 17 May 1931). American wood-engraver of English birth. He was one of the most renowned reproductive wood-engravers of his generation. Cole was apprenticed in his early teens to a Chicago firm of commercial wood-engravers and spent several years in New York, working for such periodicals as Scientific American and the Illustrated Christian Weekly. In 1875 he began an association with Scribner's Illustrated Monthly Magazine (later the Century Magazine), which continued for the greater part of his career. The magazine was a leader in 'the golden age of American illustration', and its reputation derived in part from the excellence of its engravings, to which Cole made a decisive contribution. He was in the forefront of the 'new school' of wood-engraving, which sought to reproduce more faithfully the textures and tonal values of painting and opposed the prevailing doctrines of such conservative engravers as William James Linton, who was attempting to retain some artistic licence for the engraver.
In recognition of Cole's extraordinary technical skill and his sensitivity to works of art, the Century Magazine commissioned from him a series of engravings after masterpieces owned by leading European museums. Cole spent 27 years on the project, returning to the USA in 1910 to undertake a similar commission in American museums. In addition to appearing regularly in the Century Magazine, Cole's engravings were published separately in portfolios and were used to illustrate such books as William James Stillman's Old Italian Masters (New York, 1892), J. C. Van Dyke's Old Dutch and Flemish Masters (New York, 1895) and Charles H. Caffin's Old Spanish Masters (New York, 1902).
Source: Anne Cannon Palumbo. "Cole, Timothy." Grove Art Online. Oxford Art Online. 29 Apr. 2010 .

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Suzanne J. Allan, October 19, 2011 (2011.072)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence, graduation programs, event materials, napkins, and photographs. These materials were collected by Suzanne J. Allan (nee Johnson) during her time as a student at Mount Vernon College. The material is dated from 1959-1961.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains various textiles from the Mount Vernon collection including: sports and academic uniforms, academic regalia, banners, and accessories.

did.unittitle: Navy blue Mount Vernon Seminary Uniform from Nebraska Avenue
White Mount Vernon Seminary Uniform from Nebraska Avenue
Mount Vernon Seminary Athletic Association banner

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Mount Vernon Seminary Athletic Association banner that records the winning sports teams from 1941-1964. This banner is seen in a photograph from 1943 on page 131 of "Dear Daughters."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes multiple uniforms from ca. 1940-1960. One cream, short-sleeved, button-up dress is labeled "Betsy Cann." There are also two mustard colored short-sleeved shirts labeled "Judy McAllister" and one mustard colored skort.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box contains five middies, uniforms with sailor-inspired collars, worn at Mount Vernon Seminary. Middies were popular in the first quarter of the 20th century.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box contains five middies, uniforms with sailor-inspired collars, worn at Mount Vernon Seminary. Middies were popular in the first quarter of the 20th century.

did.unittitle: Mount Vernon Seminary banner with rod

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This gold rectangular banner has a with a wooden rod and the words "Mount Vernon Seminary" embroidered on it. It has gold fringe along the bottom.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This banner is very fragile and in poor condition. It is off-white with gold tassles and has the letters MVS on it in gold.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes two white uniform blazers from Mount Vernon Junior College. One is embroidered with the name Mary C. Wayne. The other, embroidered with the name Suzanne Johnson, was donated by Suzanne Allan, class of 1961, and is pictured on the cover of the book, "Dear Daughters."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a red Mount Vernon Preparatory School Senior blazer.

did.unittitle: Five Mount Vernon College green felt banners

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Banners are forest green with gold lettering that says, "Mount Vernon College Washington, DC."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Banner is light green with gold lettering that says "Mount Vernon College Washington, DC).

did.unittitle: Mount Vernon College white felt banner

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Banner is white with gold lettering that says, "Mount Vernon College 1940-1990."

did.unittitle: Mount Vernon College extra large blue, gold, and white banner
Mount Vernon College 3X5 feet plastic banner
Mount Vernon College Washington, DC felt banner
Mount Vernon College large plastic banner with school shield
Mount Vernon College red plastic banner with school shield

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a white silk scarf decorated with images of the United States Capitol building and pink and yellow designs. "Mount Vernon College" is embroidered below each image. The scarf was made by designer Frankie Welch in Alexandria, Virginia. Welch's boutique in Aexandria was open during the 1960s and 1970s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes two pairs of wool gloves, possibly dating to ca. 1915-1930.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a creme colored wool hat with the letter "W" embroidered on the front.

did.unittitle: Mount Vernon College athletic uniforms and socks

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box contains athletic shirts, shorts, and socks from various Mount Vernon College sports teams including tennis, field hockey. Many of the uniforms are not labeled with the sport.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box contains athletic shirts, shorts, and socks from various Mount Vernon College sports teams including tennis and field hockey. Many of the uniforms are not labeled with the sport.

did.unittitle: The George Washington University at Mount Vernon groundbreaking t- shirts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes two t-shirts commemorating George Washington University's groundbreaking ceremony at Mount Vernon on April 26, 2000.

did.unittitle: Two gold tassels for commencement caps
Woven depiction of George and Martha Washington with two others

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box contains an image of George and Martha Washington and two other figures created by weaving thread through a perforated piece of thick paper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains metal objects (sterling silver, silver plated metals, brass, tin, etc.) from Mount Vernon Seminary and College. The objects include silverware, hollowware, trophies, commemorative plates, etc. and range in date from circa 1850 to 1987.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Embossed with the ABC's around the edge. On plate, embossed with "WHO KILLED COCK ROBIN. I SAID THE SPARROW WITH MY BOW & ARROW. I KILLED COCK ROBIN" as well as an image of a robin with a bow in his claw and a dead robin with an arrow in its chest.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manufactured by E.B. Mannind with a patent date of June 5, 1862

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manufactured by Wilcox Silver Plate Co., founded in 1865 in Meridian, CT.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Stamped with U.S. Patent No 89784, which was registered in 1869. Made in Japan with Japanese patent number 59402. Also labeled with Negbaur N.Y. No 256.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This piece accompanies a silver plated teapot made by E. G. Webster & Sons, a manufacturing company based in Brooklyn, NY with that name from 1886-1928.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This piece has many hallmarks on the bottom. The letters "E P N S" indicate that this piece is made of Electro-Plated Nickel Silver (often called German silver, a copper alloy with nickel and often zinc).
The six stamps above the letters are the hallmark of E. G. Webster & Sons, a manufacturing company based in Brooklyn, NY with that name from 1886-1928.
see: http://www.silvercollection.it/AMERICANSILVERPLATEMARKSTZQUATTRO.html

did.unittitle: Sheffield plate serving tray on stand

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The pinkish-orange color visible in various areas of the dish identifies it as Sheffield plate (layered combination of silver on top of copper). The combination of hallmark stamps (crossed keys, crown, and unidentifiable symbol-maybe a bell) identifies this as being made by Lawrence B. Smith Co. in Boston, MA. The company was in business from 1887 to circa 1958.
see: http://www.silvercollection.it/AMERICANSILVERPLATEMARKSSDUE.html

did.unittitle: Sheffield plate mesh dish on small stand

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The pinkish-orange color visible in various areas of the dish identifies it as Sheffield plate (layered combination of silver on top of copper). The combination of hallmark stamps (crossed keys, crown, and unidentifiable symbol-maybe a bell) identifies this as being made by Lawrence B. Smith Co. in Boston, MA. The company was in business from 1887 to circa 1958.
see: http://www.silvercollection.it/AMERICANSILVERPLATEMARKSSDUE.html

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The hallmarks on these spoons (lion, anchor, letter G) indicate that they were manufactured by Gorham Corporation Gorham Corporation, based in Providence, RI and founded circa 1815-1818.
The pattern on these spoons is called Versailles and was pattented in 1888.
see: http://www.replacements.com/webquote/GS_VER.htm (Round Bowl Soup Spoon (Bouillon))

did.unittitle: Mixed metal trophy "Presented to the Future Senior Classes of M.V.S. by the class of 1907"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manufactured by Rostand Inc., established in 1890.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This piece measures 9" wide at the base and 27 1/4" tall.
A hallmark on the bottom indicates that this piece was manufactured by the Paul Revere Silver Co. and that it is Sheffield silver (silver plated on a copper base).
The Paul Revere Silver Co. was based in Boston, MA and was in business from about 1912 to 1922.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manufactured by Paul Revere Silver Co (indicated by hallmarks), which was founded in Boston, MA in 1912.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The lion and "W" in a circle on the handle indicate that these spoons were designed by the Whiting Manufacturing Company, formed in 1866 and bought by Gorham in 1924.
The pattern of theses spoons is called

did.unittitle: Silver commemorative bowl--gift from the class of 1934

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An inscription on the bowl reads "To the Class of '35 and all succeeding Classes From the Class of '34"
A stamp on the bottom of the piece with the word "sterling" identifies this as true silver.

did.unittitle: Sterling silver large serving fork with "M.V.S." monogram

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The hallmark on this piece (an "A" in the form of a hammer with the handle extending through the word "Stone" and crossing the "t")indicates that it was manufactured by Arthur Stone's silver production company. Stone's private company was in business in Massachusetts from 1901 until Stone's retirement in 1937.
The small "H" next to the logo indicates that the pieces were manufactured between ca. 1938 and 1957, when the company was under the direction of Henry Heywood.
see: http://www.925-1000.com/a_stone.html

The small "H" next to the logo indicates that the pieces were manufactured between ca. 1938 and 1957, when the company was under the direction of Henry Heywood.

scopecontent.p: The hallmark on this piece (an "A" in the form of a hammer with the handle extending through the word "Stone" and crossing the "t")indicates that it was manufactured by Arthur Stone's silver production company. Stone's private company was in business in Massachusetts from 1901 until Stone's retirement in 1937.
The small "H" next to the logo indicates that the pieces were manufactured between ca. 1938 and 1957, when the company was under the direction of Henry Heywood.
see: http://www.925-1000.com/a_stone.html

The piece is stamped with the word "sterling" on the bottom, indicating that it is made of real silver.

did.unittitle: Sheffield plate mesh dish on small stand

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The pinkish-orange color visible in various areas of the dish identifies it as Sheffield plate (layered combination of silver on top of copper). It is known that this piece was made in London because of a stamp on the bottom. There are two other stamps: one of a hand and one of a rectangle with the letters "BB" inside it.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The tongs are decorated with a floral pattern on the handle and have bird-like claws for the tongs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains 12 prints of subjects from Shakespeare's Othello. The original series of 18 etchings was created by French romantic artist Theodore Chasseriau in 1844. Multiple print editions were made of the etchings and prints continue to be popular. The prints in this collection are undated and there is no information as to their provenance.

c.bioghist:
Biographical / HistoricalTheodore Chasseriau (b. September 20, 1819; d. October 8, 1856.) was a French Romantic painter who studied under Jean-Auguste Dominique Ingres starting at age 11. Ingres considered Chasseriau his protege and passed on the preference for drawing and modeling. Chasseriau separated from his mentor and began following the works of Eugene Delacroix an artist famous for his use of color. These two role models shaped Chasseriau's artistry allowing him to combine Classical and Romantic stylistic devices.
Chasseriau was known in his time for historical scenes and portraits, murals in churches throughout Paris, and popularising Orientalism.
Sources:
Art Directory, Fine Art Online. 04 Jan. 2012. .
Nicholas Pioch. "Chasseriau, Theodore." WebMuseum Paris Online. 04 Jan. 2012. .
